NARRATIVE-CM:
On August 15, 1914, Japan issued an ultimatum to Germany to withdraw its fleet from the Far East and to surrender the German naval base and colony in Kiaochow (Tsingtao) in the province of Shantung in northeastern China. Japan declared war against Germany on August 23, 1914. Japanese naval ships established a naval blockade of Kiaochow on on August 27, 1914, and some 23,000 Japanese troops launched a military offensive against Kiaochow on September 18, 1914. British naval ships and some 1,350 British troops intervened in support of Japanese troops. German troops formally surrendered Kiaochow to Japanese troops on November 10, 1914. Some 200 German soldiers, 415 Japanese soldiers, and 13 British military personnel were killed during the military offensive against Kiaochow. Japanese troops occupied the islands of Marshall, Mariana, Palau, and Caroline in October 1914. Germany and Japan signed the *Treaty of Versailles* on June 28, 1919, and the countries formally exchanged ratifications of the peace treaty on January 10, 1920. Japan was granted a *League of Nations *(LON) mandate over former German islands in the Pacific Ocean on December 17, 1920. German and Japanese representatives signed an anti-communist agreement on November 25, 1936. Japan nullified the anti-communist agreement with Germany on August 23, 1939.

Clodfelter, 1992, 746-747; Langer, 1972, 923, 969, 1111-1114.
